newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila short-term bills swamped on firmer rates.
newsitem.headline: Manila short-term bills swamped on firmer rates.

text.p: Short-term Philippine bills were being bought on Wednesday as cash-rich banks and corporate investors tried to park their funds for a short period in anticipation of a rising trend in interest rates, traders said.

"The short-term bills were well-bid. Buyers were locking in their excess funds in short-term bills and special saving deposits so that they can easily shift to higher-yielding instruments if the rates go up," one trader said.
Some banks were bidding three-month bills with effective yield of 10.35 percent, slightly lower than the average auction rate of 10.356 percent on Monday.
The overnight money also nudged up slightly to 13.0625 percent from 13.03125 percent amidst moderate turnover of 17.981 billion pesos.
Done rates ranged from 13.03125 percent to 13.25 percent.
Another trader said some banks have been investing in the one-month reverse repos of the Central Bank which were being offered at 10.5 percent.
Secondary T-bills trading, barring the three-month bills, was very sluggish.
"The market is dead right now. Everybody's on the selling side," another trader said.
Investors were anticipating T-bill rates to climb in the coming weeks, believing the rates have bottomed out.
